Evolution is largely misunderstood in this (as well as other) contexts. Evolution doesn't create the best/most efficient organic mechanisms and it also doesn't kill off the less-efficient-but-still-usable mechanisms. Evolution simply has the tendency to favor the more efficient traits within a population as those generally (not always) lead to fitter individuals within the species. Fitter individuals can create more viable offspring, over the course of several generations this tends to lead to the trait's prevalence within the population.

So the question "why didn't evolution create black plants?" can effectively be answered by just saying "because it didn't." There is no grand desired scheme or end-goal when it comes to evolution. Like she touched on in her video, its 100% possible that chlorophyll is "good enough" and thus it spread across the Earth because there was no need to use a more efficient process.

The last thing I'd like to say is that there is also quite a bit of "luck" when it comes to evolution. For example- it could be that halobacteria's photosynthetic pigment was once poised to become the dominant form of photosynthetic pigments, out competing chlorophyll-using organisms. But then some large-scale bottleneck effect happened and dramatically reduced the number of halobacteria and similar organisms- allowing chlorophyll to overtake it.

I think she's misunderstanding evolution.

Nothing in evolution suggests that a solution will be 'the best solution'. In fact, that would - strangely - usually be bad. Evolution is about 'the first solution that gets you to survival'. Any more than that and unless there's some actual survival benefit, the odds are good that the 'improvement' will actually make it harder for the species to pivot when the next environmental change comes along to put evolutionary pressure on the species.

Evolution is generally all about the quickest, lowest energy fix that elevates a species to survival. (There are jumps where a sudden, large change can happen - see a little later in this comment for an example... but most evolution is small changes.)

In fact, it's not even species.. it's individuals. In any population of a single species, there has to be some genetic diversity. Evolution doesn't change individuals (a common misunderstanding), it selects individuals based on their ability to survive. The ones that can get a better chance to reproduce and pass on their genes.

If there were a 'best' solution and everyone in a species got it (since by definition, it would have the evolutionary advantage over every other solution that other members of the same species might have), in a few generations, most, if not all members of the species would be using that solution.

Now, if some change in the environment made that solution a detriment - most of the rest of the population would instantly die out and some totally unexpected restart for the species would happen - assuming it isn't wiped out entirely.

Which isn't good for the species.

Nature has shown that being too efficient (eg. living forever) may actually be a competitive disadvantage, as there is less need to reproduce to survive, lowers evolutionary pressure to improve, and the individual is in vulnerable to being crowded out or out-competed.

Green plants may optimally maintain the spectrum of shared light similar to the sun's green-saturated light after a number of reflections, and the green tint may be tied to the number of useful reflections. For example, a green-leaf may reflect green light that will allow absorption of the full spectrum after 3 bounces, and thus must reflect more green to offset absorption at each stage.
